title: PLA printed gear for Rostock - 2mm pitch, GT2, 40t

description.text: A PLA printed gear/timing pulley with 40 teeth for GT2 timing belt 2mm pitch profile. Features a beefy 5mm nut/grub screw insert.

Printed at .25 layer thickness with a .5mm nozzle using PLA on a RapMan 3.2 printer. I had to adjust the depth profile of the teeth to make this fit properly but the finished product appears to grip my GT2 belts very well. This has not been used under powered condtions yet, so until I have a chance to finish building my own Rostock and to test these pulley I will call it a work in progress. 3 are required for a Rostock.

description.text:
For all those living in France, have created a clip for the toll road transponder.

Just use some double sided tape or similar to fix it on the windscreen and you are ready to use your transponder in your second car.

These designs help get the spool holders axis of rotation to the center of the spool so it doesn't vibrate around when printing and lessen the resolution capability of your printer.

These two designs are ONLY for spools with an inner diameter of 54.8 or 54.9mm. They fit like a plug and have an 80mm diameter, 2mm thick flange on them. The spools I buy are one of these sizes (check both sides). I purchase HATCHBOX PLA 1KG spool, 1.75mm.

The center hole is 7.8mm which fits the M8 150mm threaded rod that comes with the Anet A8 for the spool holder. This rod fits snug, so spin the printed designs onto the rod, and place a nut on the outside of these plugs on the rod so it doesn't spin the spool to the edge.

You need to print 1 of each or 2 of the same, you need 2 plugs..

Print with the 80mm flange side down

title: Dust Containment, Craftsman 113 Table Saw Blade Guard

description.text:
Pivoting sawdust deflector, dust cap, and dust collection hose adapters for the factory blade guard. Reduces the blast of sawdust out of the front of the guard during cutting operations.

Fits the factory guard of vintage Sears Craftsman model 113 contractor-style 10" table saws such as the 113.298142, 113.298032, and 113.298240. Dust hose adapter fits 2.5" Shop-Vac style hoses.

Use adhesive to attach the flange to the horizontal dust hose adapter. The dust cap and flanges plug (friction fit) into the rectangular opening on the upper front portion of the blade guard.

Dust hose adapters have an airflow control to allow the deflector to open when the guard is raised.

For the vertical assembly, use aluminum rivets and washers to fasten adapter to flange. As there is limited space for a rivet tool, I clamped the tail of the rivet in a vise and expanded the head with a nail-setting punch, periodically making sure that the assembly can still rotate. Rotate the cylindrical portion up to 90 degrees to increase or reduce airflow.

For the horizontal hose assembly, run a bolt through the hole in the flow control and adapter. Use washers and nylon-insert locknuts as appropriate so that you can rotate the flow control inside the hose adapter assembly to regulate flow.

The setup still needs easily-removable clips to attach and support the hose to the guard arm, and possibly a separate support arm or ceiling support to hold the weight of the hose.

comments.text:
This is mechanical instability.
If the speed increases, the quality of the print quality deteriorates because of the weakness of the printer. The same can be seen even if the dense fill causes a lot of change in the direction of the hotend and is therefore twisted, the mechanism moves.
comments.author: Gipsz

comments.text: The Slic3r print looks fine, so I don't think that the printer is mechanically limited in this case. I did some more testing and the closest thing to an explanation is the command rate in the gcode file. Printing from SD card instead of Octoprint and lowering the maximum resolution in Cura did resolve most of the problems for me. An Octoprint plugin that warns you when the command rate exceeds a certain value would probably be useful, maybe I'll look into writing plugins in the future.
comments.author: Gipsz

comments.text:
I really doubt that CURA itself is the Problem here. I have had just the opposite experience. When going from Slic3r to CURA 3x i had far better results ..especially with things like Raft adhesion, layer change artifacts or Top Layer Structure
Your CURA Prints look like a vast mismatch of Printer vs Parameters. Cura does not send such a surface structure to the Printer. The Printer creates that from the circles sent...

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dKgNROOFHXf

Parametric card holder v2

This is a list of the parametrized variables:

  • Organizer Lenght (useful if you want to put this inside a game box)
  • Organizer Height (useful if you want to put this inside a game box)
  • Card Width (card or sleeve size)
  • Card Height (card or sleeve size). This is only used in oblique dividers to prevent cards from exceeding the organizer height
  • Wall thickness (structure thickness)
  • Card slots (how many card slots do you need?)
  • Dividers vertical notch (this will help when picking a card and reduces printing time)
  • Vertical notch size (you can play with notch values to fit your needs)
  • Structure notch (it can be used as a helper to grab the holder and may reduce printing time).
  • Structure notch width
  • Attachable organizer (use this option if you need more than one organizer AND want to attach them together).
  • First organizer (do not print front connectors in this organizer)
  • Last organizer (do not print back connectors in this organizer)

I've just added an option to put text on the organizer

description.text:
This is an exeprimental model of microphone for RTX.
You can instal inside a small speaker ( max 4mm diameter )
and a micro capsule.

This is an evolution of Mike for Bitx designed some month ago.
The object define both a Mike case and a generic box to accomodate
any electric circuit.

The project was developed in collaboration with S52CQ, Jure Mikeln, that use it
in simple RTX project. Jure sent me all the images of printed box that you can see.

Thanks to S52CQ for the help and for definition of object requirements.

List of changes:

23.01.2018
This is an exeprimental model of microphone for RTX.
You can instal inside a small speaker and a micro capsule.

24.01.2018
Updated version, corrected some issues.
Added a double side box to hold internal RTX circuit and battery.

25.01.2018
Added new version (v. 2.1) with screw holes on the side.

28.01.2018
New model (3.0), changed the screws type, now I use a wood type screw with conic head
type. The head of the screws, after they have been screwed, is inserted into the lid, reducing its thickness. Furthermore, it is not necessary to use a bolt to tighten the screw, but it is inserted directly on the reinforced internal supports. I made a section of the model to perform some print tests as you can see in the attached photos. It is possible to use different sizes of screws, starting from the M3x10 for wood.

29.01.2018
Definitive version. 3.0

Best 73 de IK8YFW

description.text:
After looking at the fan designs from Helix3D, I wanted to try one but saw some issues with it. His design was large (140mm), printed in large parts with lots of supports, needed to be glued together and takes almost a whole role of filament.

I found some good information here: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/288180188_Numerical_investigation_of_geometric_parameter_effects_on_the_aerodynamic_performance_of_a_Bladeless_fan with cross sections and charts that show what parameters have the most effect on performance. So I created a version that fits an 80mm fan, can be printed in separate pieced and snapped together and is not as big an investment to print.

As Helix3D found, while the thing does work with a simple axial computer fan, those fans don't create enough pressure to properly drive the bladeless design. So in the end I can say it provides almost as much air as the computer fan does by itself. Maybe I'll take a crack at designing a turbine compressor too. (Update 1/26/18, see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2771339 for a turbine base)

Enjoy.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

I used 0.2 with a 0.3mm nozzle

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

The three Cowl pieces should be printed with the front down and the pointed edge on top. The Bottom and Middle ones need supports from the baseplate, but there should only be small ones generated for a couple of overhangs near the bottom.

The Edge piece should be printed laying down with the two U shaped edges on the bottom and no support.

Preperation:

You need two Edge, two Middle Cowl, four Feet and one of everything else.

Make sure you file down the Cowl and Edge parts where they came off the build plate. The "elephant foot" on the first layer will make assembly more difficult. Also there are a couple of 1mm supports on the first layer to help hold things in place during printing and sanding. These should be removed when you are ready to assemble.

Asembly:

Carefully insert the upper/lower cowl parts into their corresponding edge parts. You need to get the three guides slotted on one side and the whole edge in the slot on the other. Next insert the middle cowls into the bottom cowl assembly. You may need to use a small tool to help get the leading edge of the middle cowl to sit behind the leading edge of the bottom cowl. Trim or bevel the edge a bit if necessary for a snug fit without forcing it (See the second cross section). Then insert the top cowl assembly to that using the same procedure. The last step can be a bit frustrating, you might want to use tape once you get one side, so it doesn't pop out when you work on the other.

I used a rack cooling fan like this: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00D7O8NIW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 but any old 80mm computer fan should work. Attach the feet and base with M4x8 bolts and place the fan onto the base and enjoy.

description.text:
This is a shuriken I designed to look cool and be good for throwing for fun. It throws very similarly to a card, but is more stable and is slightly faster. I threw it against a wooden wall numerous times with no visible damage, but I used PETG, which is more impact resistant than PLA.

The shuriken can be thrown with the exact same styles as a playing card. Also as an extra note the direction of spin doesn't affect the flight but does affect how it bounces off of objects.

I designed it to be 1/8 inch thick and slightly blunted for safety, but when I printed it the points were still pointier than I was expecting. Thus, I designed and am uploading a more blunted version if that is desired for extra precaution.

If you like thrown objects, also check out my channeled throwing knife! It's located at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2773773.

title: Yet Another Bed Height Calibration Test

description.text:
I discovered this method while printing several small parts.

Print this cylinder near each of the 4 corners of your printer WITHOUT raft or brim (do one corner at a time). A skirt may be necessary just to get plastic to the tip of the extruder. The goal is for them to stick to the printing area without causing deformation at the base. You should be able to clearly see the hole through the bottom of the piece.

If the piece doesn't stick at that corner, move the bed at that corner up. If the base of the piece is deformed, move the bed at that corner down. Repeat until the print at all 4 corners looks good.

author: kevinb22

description.text: This is an all purpose award base. This example if using an boomerang, but could easily be swapped for a different design. I designed this for a laser cutting , on 1/4 (5mm) in Maple plywood. This particular boomerang can be engraved on both side, and removable.

I designed this to print on a 20 x 12 sheet of material, that I use in a Glowforge.
NEEDED:
1 sheet of material
Glue

  1. After cutting out the design, make sure to remove any stray material, this is a tight fit.
  2. Boomerang - Glue the three pieces together ( two boomerang pieces, and the notch piece)
    Set aside and let dry.
  3. Tower- There are five pieces to this one. I find it easiest to assemble the front ( piece that is pointy) two sides, and top. Dry fit these pieces together and hold in place, now you can apply glue to the inside corners, without the fear of it showing up on the outside. Once that is set, apply glue to the back piece, and finish assembly. This is a snug fit so you shouldn't have to brace it once assembled.
  4. Base- glue the two ovals together, the one with the large square hole goes on top.
  5. Final assembly- Apply glue to the bottom of the tower, and slide it onto the base. You have the option of gluing the boomerang or not, slide the boomerang over the post on the tower, friction will hold it in place.

comments.text: Thank you for this great idea and model.  Additional information for others......I built this at 100% and the bit fits but will slide out.  as shown in the photo, the bit has a small lip enabling you to push down on the knurl and twist.  Works great as designed. if you are using a Phillips, slotted, torx, etc bit without a lip, they will slide right through.  i built another at 95% and it was still too large for those small bits.  90% was too tight, it actual split the part trying to hammer it in for a good tight fit.  it still works well and has a good tension even though it is split.92% was just right to hold the bit in without it falling out.

I designed those having in mind that what I'm building will be subject to a lot of vibration, so solid installation was crucial.

When I attached them to the profile, I used some M6 sliding nuts, with 3 x M6x12mm socket cap screws, and 1 x M6x20mm socket cap screw.

Provided the mirror version as well.

Currently installed on a 3060 section, but it will fit on a 3030 just fine !

Feel free to ask any questions.

title: Kwintessens Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Game Design Sander ten Napel & Bert Menting.
To impress the king, players in Kwintessens try to be the best alchemist.
In ancient times, all elements were thought to be built of fire, water, earth and water, which were represented by triangles. In the game, each player tries to outwit the others by building four pure elements, i.e., triangles surrounded by triangles of the same element. To do so, the players can and probably will use the triangles played by other players.

Timing is essential in this quick, tactical game, especially since other players can break down a previously built pure element by mutating one of its parts.
One essential part of the game is the "kwintessens" triangle, which can take any shape the players want.

You will need a set of tiles per player ie 1-5 Air, Water, Fire and Earth & 4 Pawns per player.

I am very happy with how it turned out and has been working well for the past week. I will keep you posted if there are any problems.

print_settings.Notes:: As long as the parts are oriented correctly, not supports are needed.

description.text:
I designed these "F" style clamps so that I could print my own clamps and make them as long as I like with 3/4" electrical conduit. A normal 36" clamp costs between $15 - $40. You can get a 10 foot piece of 3/4" EMT conduit for as little as $4.25.

I did a crude test to see what kind of force I can get out of these clamps and got an average of 180 lbs on a bathroom scale. The most I was able to get was 190 lbs; however, the parts did not break, I just couldn't twist the handle any further.

The "dead end" of the clamp uses a #6 screw (3/4 inches long) and nut as a set screw to hold onto the conduit. The "live end" of the clamp (the end with the 3d printed screw) has two versions: one with a 3d printed latch that clamps onto the conduit, and one with a set screw like the other end. They both seem to have similar holding strength.

The latch version of the live end uses a #10 screw (1-3/4 inch long) and lock-nut to hold the latch in place.

Printer:

Creality CR10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed at 50% infill for extra strength; however, it would be worth checking to see how much infill is actually needed.

As long as the parts are oriented correctly, not supports are needed.
Fusion 360

title: METHOD - silicone baking mat bed insulation and surface adhesion

description.text:
Silicone baking mats, used for 2 things:

The much LESS interesting use:

  • The pyramidal surface mat - thermal insulation between silicone heater pad/aluminium hotbed and the Y axis chassis.
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Creative-Pyramid-Silicone-Baking-Mat-Nonstick-Pan-Pad-Cooking-Mat-Oven-Baking-Tray-Mat-Kitchen-Tools/32807788480.html
    I have been using the pyramid mat for a few months. Compared to proper stuck-on insulation this is probably quite insubstantial, but as a simple, removable method to retain and constrain heat under the bed, this works better than nothing.

The much MORE interesting use:

  • The flat mat - sticky interface between polymer 'buildtak' style bed surface and aluminium hotbed.
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Red-Silicone-Pastry-Bread-Bakeware-Tray-Oven-Rolling-Kitchen-Baking-Mat-Sheet-PML/32693285580.html
    Lay the silicone mat out matte side up, without stretching or deforming it, and check that it is flat with no ripples or deformation, and lift the corners and allow the mat to 'roll' back onto the surface to eliminate bubbles. Not all mats arrive perfectly flat, so it's possible some will not be completely appropriate to use, however heating them to 60 or 80C has been known the help them 'relax' a little into their as-produced form. So just getting it flat enough to stick a build surface to without significant tension or distortions will usually be good enough.
    A polymer build surface with adhesive on one side is stuck to the matte - NOT the shiny side - of the mat, and cut to size.
    Silicone cuts like butter, just use a sharp knife and cut slowly or it will ripple and mess up your edge.
    Note that almost nothing "sticks" to silicone in the intended sense, so in this scenario it is removable, but will not come off unless you want it to.
    The silicone mat's shiny side is applied to the clean aluminium build plate, where it will stick, and yet be easily removeable.
    Yes, I clean all of the surfaces with isopropyl alcohol. The matte side before sticking the build surface to it. The shiny side of the silicone and the aluminium build plate, before installing the silicone/surface onto the bed. Silicone likes to attract particles, so clean it and avoid putting it down anywhere until it's stuck to the relevant surface.
    This combination at first seemed a little unreliable in terms of flatness and having the required hardness to allow the nozzle to 'press' the filament into it to get intended toolpath widths, but after heating it to 60C a few times these issues seem to be gone. I'm not sure If heat rectified it or if I'm just now 'doing it right", because now I find it very easy to use, right down to 0.1mm initial layers.
    Print removal is trivial, especially when you allow it to cool completely first. Simply remove the entire surface/mat/print from the bed in a peeling motion (at which time the print usually just alls off) and carefully peel the mat/surface away from the print, IF it is still stuck.
    Realign one edge of the mat/surface with the hotbed, and roll it back into the bed. I usually swipe the flat of my NTcutter bladed scraper across the surcae to encourage any bubbled to migrate to the edges, I suspect this is useless, but it does ensure that the mat is stuck down.
    I always orient the mat/surface the same way on the bed. This may not be relevant, but consistency is important when you are testing things like this.
    Heating the silicone/buildsurface imparts a static charge that makes it cling to the aluminium. You will notice this if removing it hot. In some localities/humidities this may cause static discharge, so be careful of your electronics when peeling it off.
    The red mat is really soft. Cutting it with a blade is only difficult becasue it's so easy that the mat moves around, even when i'm holding it down with a steel ruler. You could probably cut it by pinching hard with your fingernails.
    Also useful in the kitchen, and I use an offcut to solder on, or to herd bolts/nuts.
    .
    I intend to also test the silicone mat/build surface method with the following:
    Mats:
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/WALFOS-3pc-teflon-Extra-thick-heat-resistant-teflon-BBQ-Grill-Mat-Reusable-non-stick-barbecue-grilling/32741735053.html
    .
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Bakeware-Mat-Oil-Paper-Non-Stick-Baking-Sheet-For-Pastry-Kitchen-Tool-30X40cm/32840502560.html
    .
    NOTE: The previous two items are teflon, not silicone, so obviously there may or may not be issues with prints sticking.
    They are like stiff paper...not sure if i'll bother trying to stick a square of 3m adhesive to them and try then as surfaces.. im pretty sure prints would stick to them, but they are fabric textured, and kind of crumpled from shipping.
    .
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Non-Stick-Silicone-Baking-Mat-Kneading-Dough-Mat-Baking-Rolling-pastry-Mat-Bakeware-Liners-Pads-Cooking/32799677298.html
    .
    Is like fine fibreglass fabric wrapped in a thin layer of something vaguely gummy. You can crease it, probably permanently, but if it's clean and dry it will stick to aluminium plates...not half as well as the red one, but thats almost an adhesive type of sticking... but neither will slide off a hotplate, and both can be adhered to with buildtak clone and regualr 3m sheet adhesives....and then easily removed with no damage to any component.
    .
    and surfaces:
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/SWMAKER-10pcs-Wanhao-3D-Printing-Build-Surface-220-220-mm-Square-Polyimide-Tape-sticker-build-tape/32808421081.html
    .
    This will not be stiff enough, but I may find something to mount it on.
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/SWMAKER-10pcs-Wanhao-3D-Printing-Build-Surface-220-220-mm-Square-Polyimide-Tape-sticker-build-tape/32808421081.html
    This will also not be stiff enough, but I may find something to mount it on.
    .
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/220-220-0-8mm-White-PEI-Sheet-Polyetherimide-Sheets-for-3D-Printer-with-468MP-Adhesive-Tape/32838696009.html
    This has a lot of potential, I will probably be sticking a mat to this next. The qualities of the surface material will determine how it compares; I'm sure the flexibility and removeability part will be almost identical to chinesium buildtak.

  • 2018-01-28--13-46-15
    minor update
    red silicone mat - black polymer 'buildtak' clone
    Printing 0.05mm thick first layers seems to be a lot easier than before I started using the silicone layer. I still level my bed by eye, and I have not at all been dilligent about doing it accurately for the last few weeks. Essentially just doing each corner once (frontL frontR, backR backL) and adjusting bed the usual amount ( so i can see there is a gap under the nozzle, but cant make that gap any smaller without it being obvious the nozzle is touching the bed firmly).
    I suspect that the slight amount of compliance that the silicone layer gives is allowing my nozzle height to be a little more forgiving. Possibly my 'by eye' gap estimation has also improved .
    Added photos of 0.05m initial layers... on a bed I didn't even clean properly. It seems I am being intentionally lazy about a number of things just to see if they still work because of the silicone.

  • 2018-02-11
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/220-220-0-8mm-White-PEI-Sheet-Polyetherimide-Sheets-for-3D-Printer-with-468MP-Adhesive-Tape/32838696009.html
    It's crap. Heat warps it unpredictably, it seems to like being convex. I'm not even going to try to constrain this by sticking it down.
    However this combo:
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/SWMAKER-10pcs-Wanhao-3D-Printing-Build-Surface-220-220-mm-Square-Polyimide-Tape-sticker-build-tape/32808421081.html
    and
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Non-Stick-Silicone-Baking-Mat-Kneading-Dough-Mat-Baking-Rolling-pastry-Mat-Bakeware-Liners-Pads-Cooking/32799677298.html
    Works pretty well.
    PLA is actually really difficult to keep stuck on this. I have 600 grit sanded it, and it still barely holds small prints. It's tenous if the nozzle bumps over anyhting, but it does usually hold.
    The surface doesnt stick to the silicone as well as the red stuff sticks, but it does stick. Bubbles are evident, and less easy to squeeze out becasue the thin surface is easy to distort, but none of this is too difficult ot deal with, and what bubbles and distortion from the markings on the mat I do have seem to be irrelevant by the time the nozzle hits the surface.
    I'm printing 0.04mm layers in the image I just added (2018-02-11--11-22-02.png), and i'm pretty sure the first two layers were effectively not above the surface, rather; pressed into it. Yet it's working perfectly anyway.

  • 2018-02-17
    The yellow Polyimide-Tape-sticker lifts far too easily on anyhting except tiny prints, and even then it's very difficult to stick PLA to. Pretty sure it will be well suited to PET-G though. I'll probably try using a sheed of adhesive to bind the yellow sheet to a layer of 1mm silicone I just got. Like the red stuff, but seems different somehow, tinner maybe. Will need to measure it when I start slicing and dicing.
    I have gone back to the red silicone sheet with black buildtak clone. It still lifts at the edges on larger prints, but for small quick prints it is a no-brainer to toss on the red&black sheet. Considering how relatively easy it is to print 0.04mm thick layers after leveling my bed by eye only I assume that the silicone offers some degree of latitude by squashing away from the nozzle, and presumably it's thickness/density are perfectly suited to the viscosity of PLA and feed rate.... or something thats not just pure luck that I can print 0.04 layers almost without trying. For small thin-layered prints this is now my goto surface combination.

title: Zesty Nimble adapter for TrickLaser Rostock groove mount

description.text:
Added three holes to the Basic Adapter spaced so that I can mount this on top of the aluminum triangle clamping plate on TrickLaser's kit for groove mount hot ends on a Rostock Max. The strength of the aluminum keeps my hot end clamped as rigid as ever, but with this adapter on top of it (sharing 3 longer bolts) it is still compact and light and simple.

I printed mine from ABS at 90% density, and after placing the PTFE tube in the hot end and adding the retaining clip to lock the push-to-connect fitting, I secured this and the groove mount clamping aluminum plate, with a few inches of PTFE sticking up through it all. Once fully clamped, I slid a hobby knife across the top to cut the PTFE tube flush, so that there would be no gap in the filament guidance coming out of the Zesty Nimble.

My first prints have been an amazing improvement in quality over my previous Bowden tube setup which used a Bondtech QR extruder, and even a recent test of a Bondtech BMG on the hot end itself (was too heavy and left awful vibrations visible in the prints). Single biggest improvement in performance I've seen out of any of the upgrades I've done to my Rostock.

Retort stands are useful! Chemistry labs require them (https://i.ytimg.com/vi/FcdX8obS98A/maxresdefault.jpg), some people use them for steeping coffee (https://i.pinimg.com/originals/ab/70/98/ab7098ea9709549b3eeb72145bfbbdc1.jpg), and others use a pair of them to hold printer filament (See danielkschneider's https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28590). This was designed for those who don't want to spend $15-30 for one. I am a cheapskate, and I also wanted something that I could customize. The stands are usually limited by the length of rod on the stand. Usually, the rod is threaded, but this uses a M4 set-screw on a 3/8 inch (9.53 mm) diameter rod. These are cheap and common, but they are strong enough to support a lot of weight.

You will need:

1 X 3/8" OD round rod (any length, but typically 24")
1 X 3d printed base
1 X M4-0.7 screw (thumb screw, socket, etc. per user preference or availability)

If the base needs weighted down, there are plenty of ways to add weight. Securing it to a wood block, clamping it to the table, putting a sand-bag on it, and using fishing weights on the tray of the base are a few options.

Have fun!

This is a standard lasercut box, embellished with music symbols and art. The top cutout is supposed to be raised up, and slightly rotated, and then glued back down. Looks great in maple plywood, but I've made it in acrylic as well.

This is a shelf designed for use in trailers or other situations where the stored objects have the possibility to move, the pipe design should also allow things to be hung off of the pipes, such as clothes. The top pvc pipe should prevent things from spilling out. It uses half inch pvc pipe (1/2) for the actual shelf part, while the 3D printed parts are the end caps. The inner diameter of the holes are 0.842 so it is a tight friction fit.

remixed_from.author: Gyrobot
remixed_from.title: E3D Titan Extruder Upgrade for Prusa i3

title: E3D Titan extruder for i3 - Modified

description.text:
Gyrobot's X-carriage was close to what I wanted - but not quite perfect for my needs...so...

Changes include:
Switched to a 3 linear bearing setup instead of four.
Zip tie slots slightly wider to fit my zip ties better.
Added 2 loops on the front to tie off wires from the hot end (which I ended up not being able to use.)
Added a loop on the back to tie off wires from my cooling fan and differential IR sensor.
Added a mount for the differential IR sensor.

I did all of this in OnShape, you can view/copy the files here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2e71f541012f0e76d3b84f6e/w/340e35434753e59a5d278079/e/a817b36487b914e0b47cfc91

The onshape project includes mockups of a v6 hot end, the differential sensor, and the titan.

There are still a few minor issues with this. The mesh didn't come out perfect on one of the fillets for some reason. My v6 is a few mm longer than the model I used so the IR sensor doesn't reach quite low enough - I need to adjust this to have a bit more adjustment in the sensor Z position. I also had to add some bits of cut up gift card and double sided tape to make a pad on the left side to hit my endstop without losing more X (due to the offset of the extruder I've lost almost 25mm of X with this - I'm still debating how to change things to get that back.) I may remove the two front wire loops since I wound up unable to use them - my plan was to have the wires come off the hot end on the front but when I tried that the lower block of the hot end hit the IR sensor.

I did have to print with support. Without support I was able to print it but almost always wound up having a layer shift at some point and supports made it more reliable.

Note it's upside down in the STL...I should fix that as well.

print_settings.Notes:: Supports may or may not be needed depending on the impeller. Recommend higher infill for the impellers.

title: Experimental Nerf Rival Box Mag Feeding Mechanism

description.text:
This is my feeding mechanism for a homemade rival box mag. It isn't perfect, but I haven't had the time to tune it. Hopefully this will help advance the development of large-capacity rival blasters.

Various designs of the impeller have been provided with different motor shaft hole tolerances. Top and bottom gears without "rim" in their name are basic, plain impellers meant to be a starting point to build upon. "0-2" and "0-2-5" signify 0.2mm and 0.25mm hole tolerances respectively; however you may need to adjust the model and/or your print settings for good fittings. Impellers with "rim" in their filename are the final design I used in my demonstration video.

The housing will need to have a diverter added. I used a piece of aluminum, bent it, and screwed it into place.

This setup is only reliable for official Nerf HIRs. Headshot ammo constantly gets stuck and pinched, possibly due to a stickier surface finish.

The motor used is a geared, high torque 12v motor by UXCell here: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01N990WOU/ref=twister_B074J2T8VK

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Supports may or may not be needed depending on the impeller. Recommend higher infill for the impellers.

title: OFP Nerf Rival Nemesis Pod Holder Remix to Adventure Force Tactical Strike Accelerator Motorized Ball Blaster Rail Replacement

description.text:
The little rails on the Adventure Force Tactical Strike Accelerator Motorized Ball Blaster did nothing and the pop up side ways sight was laughable at best. Reclaim that space on the blaster with room to hold extra ammo.

http://openflywheelproject.com/ had a design for a rail mounted pod holder clamp so with some careful measurements I have remixed this to fit in the groove where the rails use to set and added some holes for the mounting hardware..

Printer:

MonoPrice Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

It is important to print without supports otherwise it will fill in the little hole for the screws.

OFP Nerf Rival Nemesis Pod Holder Remix to Adventure Force Tactical Strike Accelerator Motorized Ball Blaster Rail Replacement 1 Flat - Is a single clamp in case you want to mix and match colors or align them differently on the bed.

OFP Nerf Rival Nemesis Pod Holder Remix to Adventure Force Tactical Strike Accelerator Motorized Ball Blaster Rail Replacement 4 Vertical - Will print all 4 clamps (2 for each side) in one print however there is very little bed attachment area so some people may have issues printing this orientation if they do not have good bed adhesion.

OFP Nerf Rival Nemesis Pod Holder Remix to Adventure Force Tactical Strike Accelerator Motorized Ball Blaster Rail Replacement 2 Flat - Is how I print mine, it is a quick print. Print for 1 side of the blaster and if needed print again for the other side of the blaster.

To install:
1: Remove battery door.
2: Remove 5 screws on the side of the battery door.
3: Separate battery door into 2 sections.
4: Remove 4 short wide head screws from inside of the battery door.
5: Remove rails.
6: Align hole in pod holder with hole in battery door.
7: Replace screw.
8: Repeat step 6&7 until all pod holders are affixed.

title: Ikea Lack drawer hangers for Trofast storage bin

description.text:
Use an Ikea Trofast storage bin as a drawer for a Lack table. These are drawer hangers for the Ikea Trofast storage bin. Designed to be mounted to the bottom of an Ikea Lack table using 5x60mm screws from Ikea Fixa screw and plug set. Designed and tested to not punch through the surface of a Lack table. Please measure any other table's thickness before drilling into it. Use 5+ hangers for best results.

UPDATE 2-2-18: Increased offset from 2 to 3mm. Three models available for different thickness of trofast edge. 12, 13, and 14 mm drops are included. Use whichever gives you best clearance. My Trofast edge measured ~12mm thick, and with that I would recommend using the 13mm.

Overhangs are 45 degrees
Screw hole is 5.2mm in diameter
overall dimensions 28mm x 14mm x 26-28mm
Prints as is, no need for rotation, rafts, or supports

title: Filament spool case / roller using Rubbermaid or similar containers

description.text:
Update: 2018-02-03
1) Revised roller base for 200 and 160mm diameter spools
2) Added Rubbermaid case collar, slightly longer than original

The 21-cup Rubbermaid containers are too tall for my setup. These are the 5 and 10 cup versions, together they are just perfect for 200mm diameter and up to 85mm wide spools. For 160mm diameter spools the 16 cup version is just nice.

http://www.rubbermaid.com/en-US/modular-canisters

There are similar (and cheaper) containers, I got a pair of the 5/10 cup similar containers on sale at Canadian Superstore for about $6.

base_200.stl and roller_cap.stl are printed using PLA the rest are in TPU. Rollers and caps printed at 100% infill, collar at 15% infill.

Use base_200 for 200mm or bigger diameter spools, base_160 for 160mm diameter or bigger.

Rollers use 608 bearings and are bolted to the base using m4 20mm bolts. Push bearings into the middle of the rollers where they will be held in place, then bolt the bearing with a roller_cap to the base.

Use 8mm diameter drill bit for the tube grommet.

author: jflinchbaugh

title: CR-10 MINI Bed Connector Strain Relief

description.text:
This part provides strain relief to the connector of the CR-10 Mini heat bed. Previous designs of strain reliefs for the larger CR-10 models are incorrect for the Mini, including the STLs that are on the SD card shipped with the printer.

Print:

(1) Strain Relief
(3) Spring Spacers

To install:

Connect wiring harness to header on heat bed. Align strain relief to wiring and heat bed. Retain wiring at end of part with zip tie wrapped through notches. Spring spacers may be placed between spring and heat bed, or spring and Y-axis sled, with spring in counter-bore. Install retaining screws and level bed as per standard procedure.

author: itslow

title: CR-10 MINI Bed Connector Strain Relief with Corner Clips

description.text:
This grouping of parts can be used to retain and align the stock CR-10 Mini glass bed while also providing strain relief to the connector for the heat bed. Binder clips or another retention method will still need to be used at the front of the print bed.

Print:

(1) Strain Relief Corner Clip
(1) Right-Rear Corner Clip
(2) Spring Spacers

To install:

Slide wiring harness connector through strain relief part and connect to header on heat bed. Slide strain relief back down harness and over connector and header. Retain wiring at end of part with zip tie wrapped through notches. Spring spacers may be placed between spring and heat bed, or spring and Y-axis sled, with spring in counter-bore. The non-strain relief clip should be placed at right rear of bed, but could also be placed at left front.

Some tolerance allowance is included in the parts for fore/aft and lateral positioning. Some sanding may be required if your heat bed and glass are thicker than that of the printer I measured. YMMV.

description.text:
Hello again.
This time I made a HUD Holder with Glass Mount Holder.
Recently I just got a Van, and the tires on it are oversized so it throws off my Speed by about 3-4 mph.
so I purchased a HUD from eBay installed it and worked great.
However where ever I mounted the HUD in my van the reflective image would either be twisted or double imaged.
So I designed this Holder to hold the HUD in one place and use self sticking 3M stickers to hold it in Place.
The HUD I purchased from eBay came with its own Transparent/Reflective screen, which is great but where ever I placed it didn't work. so I designed the holder to hold a piece of glass which is 1/16 inch or 2.3 mm thick which will hold the Reflective film in one spot and also not make the image from the HUD distorted.
https://www.ebay.com/itm/Q7-5-5-Car-HUD-Head-Up-Display-GPS-Speed-Warning-System-Fuel-Consumption-Au4/222621511239?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649
As you can see in the pictures it work out a lot better then I hoped.
V1 had a 2.5 mm track which worked great, but if you hit a larger bump or pot hole it fell off or moved.
Version 2 has a 2.3 mm track which keeps the glass snug and doesn't slide or pop off.
Version 2 is also a little narrower to fit exactly on steering Colum and in front of original Speedometer.
Which ever version you decide on will work, I've tried both and Version 2 works better for my needs.
.

title: Creality CR-10 Camera Mount Bracket to Frame - Interchangeable Heads!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
• 2mm walls/top/bottom.
  • I believe I actually printed this at a .3 layer height but .2 will obviously work as well.
  • 20% infill or greater
  • Print speed 60 to be safe
  • Supports aren't required for the brace but can help. The phone holder was printed upright with supports only touching the base. The GoPro adapter was flipped and printed without supports..

I was originally hoping to sell this for $1 but who am I kidding. So here it is for free, enjoy!

I designed this mount so that it can lock into the rails of the CR-10 frame and any other frame with the same dimensions. I have created three files. One is the bracket itself, one is the phone holder that is specific to my phone and the last is for mounting a GoPro or like camera. This design was meant for any variation of head to be created and attached to it. So if you are using an iphone, design up a head to hold it and throw it on!

The hole is 25.5mm in diameter and the head cylinder that goes into it is 25mm in diameter. It is a tight fit and will need to be worked in good to go in and deburring the top of the hole is a good idea. The cylinder length I used is also 25mm. I wanted to avoid any potential slope/wobble from print vibrations.

The GoPro head adapter will require a 1/4"-20 x 1 in phillips head bolt and nut as well as a small lock washer. You will have to squasher the nut in with some channel locks or you could very well suck it in by just threading the bolt through it and pulling it down.

Keep in mind if you mount it in the top z rail you will have to make sure your printer will not run into it if its a tall print.

Add a small piece of kitchen drawer grip between the head and bracket if you are worried about it spinning to easy after wear in.

Check out the YouTube video and subscribe to my channel for future designs and builds! Thanks and share if you make one!

https://youtu.be/uT33y-Ep4BM
https://youtu.be/IHLrtbf5p88

title: Bannilite Cam Strut Insert
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The cam strut insert that soft mounts the FPV camera in the Bannilite frame. Print in TPU.

This piece ships with the Bannilite kit. It provides correct spacing for the RunCam Micro Swift (19mm), but the primary reason it exists is as a tear-away piece that can be destroyed in a catastrophic crash to stop your camera being torn in half. Basically, if you smash the nose of the camera such that the struts and braces are shattered, the camera has a shot at surviving. Without this piece, it would likely be torn in half when the first brace breaks. The Bannilite kit comes with these pieces, as well as spare camera braces, struts, and cam strut inserts so you can repair and get back in the air, hopefully on the same camera.It provides correct spacing for the RunCam Micro Swift (19mm), but the primary reason it exists is as a tear-away piece that can be destroyed in a catastrophic crash to stop your camera being torn in half. title: Keyhole mount clip for rectangular tubing

description.text:
This is an adapter to hang my mailbox from that clips on to my porch railing. The railing is a rectangular tube 38.5mm wide by 19.6mm thick. The mailbox has a keyhole-style hanger with a large diameter of just over 8mm and a small diameter just over 4mm. The back panel of the mailbox is recessed about 13mm from the back edges of the frame and lid.

I printed a pair of adapters and clipped them onto my porch railing, then hung the mailbox from them. It probably would have been better to model this as two parts and to have the pegs screw in to the clip (or just be standoffs with holes in to accept a real screw) but this worked well enough.

This is pretty specific to my situation, but if it helps someone out I'm glad to help.

title: iPhone X and Apple Watch Wireless Charging Base

description.text:
This is a wireless charging based meant to work with the iphone x or other iphones that work with the wireless charging and the apple watch. I designed this around the Cubevit charger on Amazon, link below. The 4 port USB charge brick provides power to the wireless charger, the apple watch charger. The other two ports are used for an extra lightning charger and extra micro USB charger. I used 1 foot cords for that. I bought the short apple watch charging cable directly from apple. I use the short 90 degree micro usb cable to go from the back of the wireless charger to the USB charger. The 90 degree power cord is more convenient and looks better. The white power cord that came with the USB charger is good enough if you want to save money. You can use a small 2 port USB charger if you dont need the extra power cables. I used the bigger 4 port brick to add weight and stabilize the base. Feels solid. You can add some rubber feet if its on a smooth surface. I spent about $75 all told which is a lot, but its very functional and I use it every day and take it when i travel. The extra micro USB and lightning cables are extremely useful when my wife or kids forget their chargers.

4 Port USB Charging brick: ( this comes in black now) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OT74FIS/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

90 Degree Micro USB Cable: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LZ6458B/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Iphone Wireless Charger: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B077B4ZQQP/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

90 Degree power cord: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IBIC794/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Short apple watch charging cable: https://www.apple.com/shop/product/MKLG2AM/A/apple-watch-magnetic-charging-cable-1m

I also bought a 1 foot micro usb and lightning cable, but there are lots of options for those.

author: butterfreeism

description.text:
Adquirí un kit de la impresora 3D Anycubic Kossel Pulley, la cual no tenia soporte para el filamento. Para ir tirando utilizaba el soporte del rollo del papel de cocina, pero tenía que ir ayudándole para que no se liara. Me baje uno para ponerlo en el perfil de la impresora, pero al ponerlo, sin querer, al apretar los tornillo, partí uno de los cables del motor del extrusor. Hecho el empalme decidí quitarlo. Cuando las piezas son pequeñas, por lo menos yo, me quedo embobado viéndolas y no me da pereza estar pendiente del filamento, pero al hacer piezas más grandes, llega un momento en que tienes que dormir, jeje. Por esto decidí diseñar un soporte.
Por la casa tenía un par de rodamientos que junto con un tubo metálico de un armario obsoleto y una tubería de gas de cobre hice la pieza metálica que veis en las imágenes. Decir que los rodamientos no son necesarios pero cuando la bobina de filamento está entera el peso puede hacer que no gire bien, por eso nos gusta ponerle rodamientos.
A parte del vástago metalico, el cual os invito a que lo hagáis impreso, el invento consta de 3 piezas:
Un vástago con más diámetro para que el rollo asiente bien.
Una tapa para que el rollo no se salga,
Y una base para montar el vástago.
Las dos primeras las hice con una resolución de 0,2 y un relleno del 20%.
La base decidí hacerla a 0,3 con 3 perímetros y el mismo relleno. La personalización es para gastar menos plástico, así como las figuras en los lados, fijarse que todos los angulos va a partir de 60º para no tener que generar soportes.
Os dejo los stl y los ficheros en formato Freecad (software libre) para que podáis adaptarlos a las tolerancias de vuestra impresora y mejoréis el diseño. Asimismo pongo los ficheros de los perfiles de Cura.

Traducción Google:
I bought a kit from the 3D printer Anycubic Kossel Pulley, which had no support for the filament. To pull it used the paper roll roll holder, but had to go helping him not to get involved. I took one down to put it in the profile of the printer, but when putting it, unintentionally, when tightening the screws, I split one of the cables of the extruder motor. Done the splice I decided to remove it. When the pieces are small, at least I am stunned watching them and I am not too lazy to be aware of the filament, but when making larger pieces, there comes a time when you have to sleep, hehe. That's why I decided to design a support.
For the house I had a pair of bearings that together with a metal tube of an obsolete closet and a copper gas pipe I made the metal piece that you see in the images. Say that the bearings are not necessary but when the filament coil is full the weight can make it not turn well, that's why we like to put bearings.
Apart from the metal rod, which I invite you to make it printed, the invention consists of 3 pieces:
A shank with more diameter so that the roll seats well.
A lid so that the roll does not come out,
And a base to mount the shank.
The first two I did with a resolution of 0.2 and a filling of 20%.
The base I decided to make it at 0.3 with 3 perimeters and the same filling. The personalization is to spend less plastic, as well as the figures on the sides, to be fixed that all the angles go from 60º to not have to generate supports.
I leave stl and files in Freecad format (free software) so you can adapt them to the tolerances of your printer and improve the design. I also put the files of the profiles of Cura.

Anycubic Kossel Pulley

title: ScatterBlocks: Cyclopean Stone (28mm/Heroic scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
KICKSTARTER ALERT!

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

PLUS- backers at the $25 level will get the play test starter kit for our new game, Wrath & Ruin, a blend of simple miniature wargaming and physical boulder-throwing (check out the video). We're pretty excited about this one, and would love to get others in on the play testing phase before we expand and go wider with the game.

Nothing fancy, just some stone-textured building blocks for assembling quick-build/take-down scatter terrain. Each block is designed to fit into a standard grid map (if you're using such a thing). Shown with some models from the Dark Souls and Massive Darkness boardgames. No support material necessary. I printed mine at a .2 layer height with 10% infill. I print mine in black filament (ABS or PLA) and paint without priming (just a quick dark grey with a light grey drybrushing). I'm always surprised by how much the paint coat's natural friction does to keep these kinds of models in place.

If you like our stuff here on Thingiverse and want to support us in creating more free models and pick up some exclusives (like our Z.O.D. terrain tile series or our upcoming miniatures game, "Teledrome") check us out on Patreon! (Psst... we take requests and commissions as well...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is an alternate mounting system for the Hictop CR-10S spool holder. Instead of attaching the holder to the control box, this mount lets you attach it to the top of the printer, directly onto the frame.

The mount is designed to grip the CR-10S' frame using inserts that match its X-shape lateral grooves. If printed with reasonable quality, the part with go in without any force, and the leverage from the spool will lock in in place. The mount also features two holes designed to fit the CR-10S' spool holder's screws.

The system overall feels much tighter to me now, as the filament is no longer attached to two potentially moving pieces (printer & control box). Instead, the spool is now always at a very specific position relative to the extruder infeed, even when the printer (or the control box) is moved.

Also (and this was the original reason for making this), this mount has also opened up a significant amount of space on my work area as I can now fit the control box in a much tighter spot than before.

Printer:

Hictop CR-10S

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Since this mount holds the spool using leverage against the frame, the part needs to be sturdy. You should print the model such that its inserts (the things that go in the printer frame grooves) are oriented vertically. This will ensure that the stress of a heavy spool is distributed across all of the printed layers, rather than causing two layers to split apart.

I recommend printing at fairly high quality, as the fit is reasonably tight and a sloppy model won't fit in the printer frame grooves (or the spool holder screws might not fit in the model's holes). I used 0.1mm layer height with a .4mm extruder at 50% infill, 60mm/s, 3 top/bottom/outline. This produced something that easily slides in, yet feels really solid. YMMV

Oh, and yes, you have to unscrew two of the frame's screws in order to be able to slide the part in. You don't need to unscrew the Z axis rod though. I'm sure you'll figure it out :)

title: Loki's Helmet for 1:6 scale action figures

description.text: Loki's helmet from "Thor" and "The Avengers," thickened and scaled down to be worn by a sixth-scale action figure with the Hot Toys "Loki" head -- or, at least, the Hot Toys knock-off I got on eBay! Head sizes can vary, so some rescaling may be needed for your purposes. I printed this with a width of 2.05 inches.

I shrank Jace1969's excellent Helmet for Loki, thickened the walls a bit, and widened it slightly so it will fit over the ears of a Hot Toys Loki Head (or at least, the Hot Toys knock-off Loki Head I bought on eBay.)

It's the thickening of the walls that leads me to post this separately. I did it in the cheesiest way possible, because I'm a rank noob -- I cloned the object, reduced the clone to 99% size, and merged it with the original -- but that gave me an end result that had the solidity of an action figure accessory, whereas, when reduced to sixth-scale, Jace1969's version, intended for cosplayers, was so thin it was almost paper.

title: Heavy duty spool holder for Geeetech Mecreator 2

description.text:
My filament spool fell once and took down the Raspberry Pi that was running the print via Octopi. "Never more" I thought and started designing this over the top heavy duty spool holder!

There are 3 inserts for optional magnets on the bottom.

Printer:

Geeetech Mecreator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

2

Notes:

Print diagonally.
The supports are a pain to get out but I managed to get the job done with a small swiss army knife.
Both parts ended up a bit stringy on the sides, I used a lighter to correct that (barbaric, I know - you can use a heatgun).

Instructions
  1. Print 2x the included model
  2. Remove the support material
  3. OPTIONAL: Place 3 8mm (3mm deep) magnet on the bottom (you may want to use glue)
  4. Put spool on the filament spool holder
  5. Place the two bearings on the universal spool holder
  6. Put threaded rod through the universal spool holder
  7. OPTIONAL: Use a second threaded rod to connect both holders (on the bottom)
  8. Thread in the M8 nuts
  9. Place on printer and enjoy your filament spool NOT falling ever again.
Parts checklist
  • A print of the universal filament spool holder
  • 2x 15cm M8 threaded rods. Can be printed
  • 4x M8 bolts. Can be printed
  • 2x 608ZZ ball bearings

title: Librarian Terminator Warhammer 40.000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Librarians are the psykers of the Space Marines who survive an Adeptus Astartes Chapter's rigorous screening and training to bend the powers of the Warp to their will for the benefit of their fellow Battle-Brothers and in service to the Emperor of Mankind. Beyond their psychic duties, the Librarians of the Astartes are also expected to record the great deeds of their Chapter and maintain the Chapter's storehouse of ancient lore, the functions for which they are named. A Librarian is often estranged from the other members of his Chapter. This is usually because the psychic abilities he possesses are what his brother Space Marines are often expected to abhor and purge in most other beings. Space Marine Librarians use their abilities to serve the various undertakings of their Chapter; however, their actual place in the order of battle is always with the Librarium in a Codex Astartes-compliant Chapter. As the name suggests, the Librarium is a place within a Space Marine Chapter's fortress-monastery where the Chapter's vast knowledge base, gathered over millennia of hard-fought battles and participation in engagements the length and breadth of the galaxy, is stored.

description.text:
This is an extensible round stock measuring tool. Each segment is 150mm long. You can print additional segments and connect them with printed pins and an M5 bolt. There are 5mm holes in the plate for mounting to a bench. You can place the tabs into the slots get different measurements. There is pretty good repeatability in my tests. The tabs subtract 5mm to 14mm from the slot they are placed in. For example, if you place the -9mm tab at 130mm, the usable channel is 130-9=121mm. The pen attachment was designed around a Sharpie Ultrafine marker. I looked at several common markers and they all seem to taper, so the holder is a compromise and will not fit over the entire length of the marker. I have also included a 12mm version for larger pens. The center of the pen adapter is 15mm from the edge of the segment. You could design your own attachments for the front or back if you desired. You can also use the tool without a pen dapter.

Please note that the white colored unit in the pictures is an older revision. The blue unit is the current revision.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Variable

Notes:

description.text:
Minimalist almost all printed enclosure for Prusa MK2S (will probably fit many other printers), with led strips, hepa + carbon filter and additional fans to protect electronics and power supply.
Work not finished, still missing the filament guide to cover the upper hole (very rough now), the clips to block the door in closed position, the clips to cover the openings between plaxiglass parts, the covers for the side openings, and an electronics box for the fans/leds connections.
But already very nice looking and working, even without being completely sealed it keeps heat inside and stabilized on a good 30-40C during 2 hours long PET print (to be better measured...).
One note, I have sorbotane supports on the bottom of the printer feets (increasing height by 1-2 cm), and when the extruder moves all way up it touches the plexiglass (upper plexiglass is ~1 mm too low). I solved by cutting 1-2 mm from the extruder top but is not very nice looking it might be better to increase box height by 1-2 cm, 40 cm height was a bit toolow for the MK2S...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in ICE Brave Black PETG.
Supports only for upper parts where you cannot orient all walls vertically. For next prints increase clearance of the 3 mm grooves because the fit was too tight (mostly on parts with supports due to bad supports surface), I reworked the grooves with a dremel 3 mm point and after they fit well.
I blocked all parts with standard glue just to be sure but it should all stay together by press-fit, then they are screwed to the bottom plate.
The plexiglass were 50x50x0.3 cm plates cut to: 40x50x0.3 (sides), 10x50x0.3 (sides back), 25x40x0.3 (door) and 40x10x0.3cm (top back) plus one 50x50x0.3 not cut for the top.
the windows for the filter and the side openings have been made with the dremel to fit the nice filter https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2105113 (thanks to the designer!).
The filament opening on top has been made with dremel again, has to be redone better and I still have to print and add a PET plate to cover the cut leaving a proper entering for the filament with a chamfer.
The base is plain wood pianted in white, cut and drilled.

Electronics:
I used the spare 12V exit of the printer power supply and attached the three led strips (one on the printer, two on the box), the fans for electronic box (another very nice design here kudos to the authour https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2288236 ) and for power supply (fan 80 mm attached with simple wood screws and a rubber shim to the power supply grill).

Took inspiration from a non finished design of a small pexiglass box connections parts, made something similar with sketchup by inserting the plexiglass plates, paralelepiped shaped elements and then cut the plexiglass from the connecting elements. Then I cut the conneting elements and added the details.

title: RealAcc X6R-250 Quad Top Arm Cover

description.text:
RealAcc-X6R-250mm Quad Frame came without Top-Plate. Without this Plate, each Arms would only be kept in place by 3 Bolts. But with this Top-Plate, with enough Thickness, each arms are now supporting each other. Which makes this structure more Sturdy. Also, it is not pleasant to look at Bare-bone 4 Carbon-Fiber Arms Not meeting together at the center nicely.

I printed "Body_v2_t2.5", since 2.5mm Thickness gave me enough room above the plate to mount Flight-Controller and PDB.

I do not recommend Thin-versions(1.5mm, 2.0mm) because that wouldn't be effective for supporting the structure. That is one of the most important reason why Top-Cover exists!

A very simple, hookless tatting shuttle.  Shuttle tatting is a technique for handcrafting beautiful laces by means of a small shuttle that holds and guides the thread.

There are two sample STL files:
  • tatting-shuttle-full.stl: a complete tatting shuttle;
  • tatting-shuttle-half.stl: just half a tatting shuttle for easier building.
    • You can build two halves (tatting-shuttle-half.stl) and then bond or weld them together. I made several out of ABS and solvent-welded them with cement made out of ABS scraps dissolved into acetone. There are several geometrical parameters that can be changed. The attached drawing shows them; they are expressed in millimeters. You can edit the SCAD file to make a shuttle that suits your needs. In addition to the dimensions, there is a boolean parameter, half_model, which can be set to true in order to build just half a tatting shuttle. With a little effort, you can give your shuttle a gorgeous look. Use a file to smooth the rough edges and, if you build your shuttle in ABS, try to use an acetone-soaked brush to give it a smooth, glossy, almost-pearly finish. This thing can be seen as related to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10182 (a net-making shuttle) and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6193 (a weaving shuttle).

comments.text: This inspired me to try tatting again, I learned about 10 years ago.  Thanks!  I like shuttles with points, but am not sure how to add them to the OPENScad. title: AR 15 Front Pivot Pin Installation Tool x2

description.text:
I figured that since this was not a heavy spring that we are installing, why worry about it having to be metal. I plan on making a pair of these in PLA soon.

there are lots of videos out there on how to use these... but the short version is thus...

insert one through the pin retaining flanges.
align it so that the hole is allowing you to put the spring and the detent through it and into place.
then using the smaller end, drive the detent in far enough that you can rotate the assembly.
align the pivot pin and drive it in, allowing the tool to slide out at the same time. this will allow the detent to catch on the hidden flat part of the pivot pin and waa-laa... done.

be aware that the detent will eventually wear on the tools, but if you are doing enough assemblies to worry about that... consider getting some good steel ones and be done. this is more intended for hobbiests that are just doing... I would guess a dozen or less.

Print in flex material. Frame is designed for friction fit. Secure the motor mounts with zip ties. Kills a ton of vibrations.

This is a hamster wheel I designed, it is very easy to print and assemble, in total there are 4 printed parts and then you need some nuts and bolts listed below:

  • 4x wood screw 3*15L
  • 1x M8 threaded rod 90mm long.
  • 3x M8 nut
  • 2x speed ring.
  • 1x 8mm ID and 11mm long spacer. (between the bearings)

I did fill the sockets where the M8 rod rests with some epoxy to keep it in place.

  • The assembly of the base is pretty straight forward.
  • The bearings can be pressed into the wheel with the 11mm spacer in between them.
  • Slide the rod through the bearings and put 1 nut and 1 speedring at the closed side of the wheel. Leave approx. 10mm sticking out from the nut.
  • Put another speedring on the rod on the open side of the wheel, then put on 2 nuts so they lock eachother. You could use 1 nut and loctite as well.

You're done! Just place the two ends of the rod in the socket on the vertical stands and glue them in to place so they can't move.

title: Phone holder for Focus or Leaf, Portrait or Landscape, easy to modify

description.text:
This is a flexible FreeCAD design for a phone holder which fits into an air vent and holds your phone either portrait or landscape without any adjustment. The parts here are for a OnePlus 2 phone but work with most larger smartphones. The part which varies from car to car is the lower clip and I've included one for a Ford Focus and one for a Nissan Leaf.

The FreeCAD file is easy to modify to get the dimensions for your particular phone and/or car vent. The upper clip only has to be moved in the Z axis to fit the portrait width of your phone.

The lower clip needs adjusting to your particular air vent design and the length of the long part of the clip adjusted to fit the phone's landscape height up to the upper clip. The separation between the lower clips is: a snug fit in the air vent, but not so far apart the phone falls through(!)

There's no need to be very accurate on the dimensions, for example these work fine for a Nexus 5X, just with a bit more wiggle room.

Have fun!

title: Clip to stop Z axis linear rods rotating on Sintron Prusa i3

description.text:
I mounted the z axis limit switches on the z axis linear rods. This works ok except for the fact that the rods can rotate, moving the limit switches and stuffing up their calibration and triggering. This clip bolts on to the holes in the top support for the z axis linear rods. I think these holes were meant to have plates screwed over them to stop the rods falling out, but I never got around to it. As well as stopping the rods turning, this clips also stops the rod falling out.

All screws and nut are various lengths of M3.

I only bothered printing one clip for the side with the limit switches, as I do not particually care if the rod on the other side rotates.

There are various versions of the design available, with different mounting holes and the screw head for the clamp and nut on other side.

Please note that after taking this photo I mounted the clip upside down under the acrylic support instead of on top of it. This allowed the clip to grab more of the rod and it is extremely hard to shift now.

title: Universal filament sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a 3D printed Filament sensor.
It will warn you of blocked filament or broken filament.

The arduino waits for a certain time to pass. If the sensor didn't put out any HIGH or LOW signal the arduino will respond with a continuous beep until the filament moves again.

Ps. I configurated the arduinosketch to work with a vary of 3dprinters, but if may be possible that you need to change the values of the sensor depending on what is your printspeed.(instructions written in arduino sketch)

BOM:

  • Arduino (Uno, mega, mini,etc) (i have uploaded the sketch)
  • 2x 608 bearings (8mm inner diameter)
  • 2x 5cm M8 rod.
  • 9x M8 nut
  • 2x M8 washer
  • simple buzzer
  • Speed sensor arduino
  • Double sided tape (you need to put it on the 2 guide wheels to prevent slipping rotations)

NOTE.----- MARLIN firmware users I am working on a solution to connect this sensor directly to your motherboard of the printer, when the sensor gets triggered he will pause the print and wait for user interaction.
When i finish this i will post the extra code but while you wait, feel free to use this instead!

title: Parametric Printed SilkScreen w/ optional frame and squeegee

description.text:
Converted the business card into a silkscreen stencil with optional frame and squeegee of the exact size. Also added optional text with, or in place of, image. Many thanks to Anoved for pointing out how to get write.scad to work in the customizer. For some reason I can't respond to his comment, but the help is much appreciated and text now works online. For offline use, you need Write.scad and Letters.dxf from HarlanDMii I've tested it now, but the size of text was really too small to print with my printer. The result is pictured above. It half worked. A larger pattern should be fine. Also, Cura is dropping out the grid lines at 0.2mm and 0.3mm line width. I've asked in their forum what is the minimum Cura will NOT drop out. Update: It's the " shell thickness" setting in Cura that makes all the difference, no matter the machine Nozzle diameter. That is, at least as far as what it /tries/ to print. I'm not saying I can actually print a finer line, but setting the shell thickness to anything less than the size of the lines causes them to show up. As suggested by a friend on Google+, it might be better to spray glue a screen to the print bed and then print PLA over it. That would provide a fine screen and allow you to 3D print rather than photographically expose silkscreen emulsion. Possible problems:
  • Not sure how fine the silkscreen grid needs to be, or how thick, or how wide, or...
  • Wish it were easier to provide multiple lines of text. (Any ideas?)
  • The first layer is everything on this, so getting it to adhere is key.
    • Update 20141204:
    Had a problem in customizer where it would preview fine and then throw multiple "WARNING: Imported file (write/Letters.dxf) found in document root..." and "ERROR: Object isn't a valid 2-manifold! Modify your design." messages and fail to create an .STL file. I spent hours messing about to figure out why and eventually figured out the problem was the squeegee; if you set the squeegee height to 0 it rendered just fine! I've changed the polygon for the squeegee and it appears to work correctly now. If it doesn't work for you, let me know and try with the squeegee height set to 0, or if you want that, install OpenSCAD and download files for offline use. I also added tabs to organize the options, and added support for the new format of poly data from Stencil-o-matic. Update 20141205: Rearranged the tabs and changed defaults to more reasonable settings. The main thing is the width of the screen grid lines can't really be smaller than the diameter of the print nozzle. So I defaulted it to 0.5 now since that's generally the largest one anyone has.

• STATUS: Seems to work fine in OpenSCAD offline, and appears to work now in Customizer
    • Step 1: Download for OpenSCAD, or open in customizer, then change text and input image. If you just want text, delete the input, if you just want an image, paste in an array of pollygons (see http://chaaawa.com/stencil_factory/ for an easy way to copy a poly array from your logo). Mess about with the other settings to get it all in and how you want it. Step 2: Download and print. If the screen doesn't come out, adjust settings and try again. Step 3: With sharp scissors or knife, cut off the squeegee. Step 4: Place over material to be printed, Add paint to one side, then draw it over the surface with the squeegee. Lift and admire.

comments.text: Argh. If anyone else is unable to respond to comments, unable to see anything on the "Comment" tab, or seeing comments only under the "Thing info" but not under the "Comment" tab, it's probably because of the Avast browser extension. The "Block social networks" setting in the extension options causes it to not work. In Chrome, go to the triple equal sign in the upper right corner (just under the close window X) and pull down the menu, then go to Settings, and then to Extensions (on the left). Find the Avast extension, go to "Options" and UNcheck the "Block social networks"

title: Audio-Technica ATH-M40X Replacement Hinge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement hinge for the Audio-Technica ATH-M40x headphones. This is the most complex thing I've made in AutoCAD so far and there have been quite some prototypes before I got to this version.

Note
This replacement is compatible with the stock pin/peg of the headphone. No cutting of wires needed!

Note 2
The speaker part is able to rotate fully. If you want to prevent the wire twisting, you can tighten the bolt/nut combination to prevent this.

Additional Materials
Besides one screw used from the old hinge (the one attaching the inner piece to the metal plate), you'll need 2 M3 bolts and 2 M3 nuts per side. I use M3x20mm bolts, but these can be replaced by shorter ones after the nuts have been dragged into the hexagonal holes.

This is a solid of constant width, or should be anyway.

It exhibits a property that it shares with spheres which is you can use it as a ball bearing, it's just not a ball, but if stuck between parallel planes, it should roll and the planes won't wobble.

This one is based on a tetrahedron and a sphere is placed at each corner. The face opposing each corner is a portion of that sphere.

I give you the OpenScad file to play with and the STL to print direct.
Advice : place the shape on it's tip by using a 45° rotation on X and 35 rotation on Y
scale it up a bit (x2)
place 3 on your build plate
choose 10% infill

description.text:
I call this Lunar Lander, for obvious reasons.

A pendant light built from hubs that allow the creation of space frames. The hubs are twist rhombic dodecahedra. Other 3D printed parts are a flange for holding the cardboard triangles, a jig for centering the holes in the wooden discs, and a ball for the bottom struts.

The holes in the dodecahedra are sized for 3/16" dowels.

Notes: in assembly be mindful that the space frame becomes VERY rigid so don't count on being able to bend the dowels to insert new struts between hubs. The light socket is attached to a triangular piece of 1/4" wood that is connected to three center struts.

The wooden discs are available here: https://www.caseyswood.com/shoppingcart/zen-cart/index.php?main_page=index&cPath=54

Cord and socket hardware for the light here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OZRF798/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: 50W HF amplifier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an enclosure for an amplifier for amateur radio. It is part of a comprehensive project covering all major aspects of an efficient DIY design, leading to a minimalistic, but field deployable device. Its main characteristics are:

  • 30 to 50 W output
  • 2 to 2,5 W input
  • 12 V to 14 V supply
  • Works 40 m to 20 m bands, expandable
  • Harmonics Suppression via LPF
  • PTT (active low)
  • Passive cooling, ready for active venting
  • Time required for building: 6 to 8 h
  • Total hardware cost: approx. 50 €

The technical design is based on an amplifier kit which is readily available online at favorable terms. Compliance with regulations is ensured by adding switchable low-pass filters for which a PCB layout is provided. Last but not least this 3D printed enclosure provides convenient mounting and protects the whole system.

More detailed documentation and supplemental material (PCB files, drilling templates...) is available on my website: http://www.oe1cgs.at/50w-hf-verstaerker/ (Deutsch, with extended englisch abstract and many pictures).

Bq Hephestos i3

20%

Notes:

I printed with PLA on a heated bed (60°C). Use ABS for superior endurance.Resolution for the backpanel, clamps and spacers was 0,2 mm. For the frontpanel a resolution of 0,4 mm is sufficient.

Only the backpanel needs support ("touching buildplate").

In addition to the printed parts the following material is needed to build the enclosure:

  • 4 screws M3 x 10 mm (or longer)
  • 4 nuts M3

description.text: Fun toy for your office Desk or Gift to a really nerdy Friend Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hNPXel2_7ho&feature=youtube_gdata_player

1)Obtain 32oz Nalgene bottle
2)On black Cap, carefully cut threads to allow for the Cap to spin freely
3)Glue collar to inside Lip of the Nalgene bottle (Super glue or hot Glue)
4)Hot Glue Combo lock to center of the inside of the Cap
5)Add a colored stripe in the Three spots of the combo (This will be the reference line)
6)Starting at Notch in the collar, number around the bottle 0 to 9 counter clock wise (CCW) Trick: insert combo in the collar and eyeball the location of the grooves to add numbers
7) Optional: Use acetone to remove Graphics on the bottle
8) Add PI or Easy as PI to the bottle with a marker
9) Add candy or a Prize to the Bottle
10) Twist on Cap And Enjoy the Fun Puzzle toy!

title: Threaded Rod Ends for Ferrari Part #61326200

description.text: Left and right threaded rod ends for Ferrari part #61326200. The original plastic parts from the manufacturer are NLA, as is the entire assembly. These parts are designed to attach to the original (metal) adjuster.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Recommend solid

Notes:

Parts should be printed/manufactured of high-strength/high-heat materials (not basic PLA) due to the stresses the part is under. Part location is also subject to the elements. Ideally, part would be manufactured out of a self-lubricating HDPE or something similar.

Have personally printed these and fit them against the original parts using a 50% infill and it seems to be strong enough, but haven't done long term tests. Given the amount of stress this part can be under (the motor it is connected to is very strong), recommend solid printing.

Note: If you do not print supports, print these parts vertically, with the threaded end at the top. Seems to print very well this way on the Replicator 2 I'm using.

Due to printing tolerances, you may have to chase the threaded portion with appropriate left/right handed M6 X 1.0 tap. Left hand thread part has an engraved L on the face.

May also have to smooth the inside of the connection hole for proper fit to the original metal pivot arm - rod end should rotate freely around pivot arm with no play. Recommend lubricating this connection to reduce wear on plastic part.

Assembled to original adjuster and pivot arm. No post printing changes. C clip ultimately holds the rod end on the pivot arm. Pity about the green color, but it's the only filiment I had on hand. You can see the L engraved on the left threaded part.
