author: justwind

description.text:
This is a typeface designed to be 3d printed or rendered-
The design uses 1mm wall thicknesses which seem to print very nicely on all 3d printers, and the simple and iterative appearance mimics heat sinks.
After making a few I couldn't stop until I had made them all because they were fun to play and interact with!
Each block is about 2" square. I have also included a few alternate letter designs. You can follow some of the progress of how I changed the letters on my instagram account for #3dprintaday.
Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a rear tail Ski for the Durafly Tundra. I tried to design it to match the front Skis already available by Bob. A nice set of black elastic bands or o rings make this look alot neater.

I will need support to print but only uses it on the overhangs and holes.

If you position your bands right you will also get resistance when the Ski moves down so the chance of it sinking is reduced. I included a hole however if you wish to use some fishing line to limit the pivot on the Ski.

Good Luck i happy landings. Sadly the snow has disappeared here so i wont be able to test this design myself yet.

description.text: This is a thumb wheel for the bed leveling adjustment on the Wanhao i3 Plus. This is designed for the nut to be inserted part way during the print process. I used S3d to slice this part in 2 processes. The first process prints up to 4.6mm height and then the nut is inserted. The 2nd process completes the print. I sliced each process as a separate job file, but you can simply add a pause at height instruction in your gcode if you prefer. I would suggest that you measure the nut height before slicing to ensure you pause at the correct height.

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

~20%

Notes:

With these print settings, the top/clamp piece is 16 layers high. I wanted this piece solid, so that I could clamp it with some force, so I set top and bottom layers to 8 layers each. This allowed me to print both parts at the same time, get solid infill on the one, and whatever else infill I wanted on the other.
I glued the two parts together with 5 minute epoxy and a spring clamp, but really any decent glue should work. Just make sure the parts are at a right angle to each other while the glue is curing.

title: Furibee Darkmax 220 Motor Guard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Motor guards for a Furibee Darkmax 220 quadcopter. The motor housings seem to be like mud magnets everytime I eat dirt with the quad so I designed these guards to cover them and take the worst of the mess. I haven't been out for a fly/crash with them yet as the wind is gusting too strong, but they appear to fit fine, robustness to damage is yet to be determined. Base and walls are 2.4mm thick, you will need longer screws than the stock ones to fit them. Weight is 6.6g a piece.

Update 26/01/2018 - Test flown and they seem to work pretty well and appear reasonably robust albeit I am improving and only crashed a couple of times, they did get dirty though.

description.text:
After designing and using my original vape stand for a while (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2450149) we started to accumulate a number of 60mL and 100mL juice bottles, and a bunch of additional tips and such that my original design didn't accommodate. So, I dove back in and designed a bigger version to hold more/bigger bottles. The bottle slots are all sized for 100mL, but can hold 60mL or 30mL without too much jiggling around.

Additionally, I added a drawer at the base of the stand that is deep enough to hold an additional iStick pico, plus some spare batteries, coils, tanks, and tips.

The drawer's sides and bottom are all designed at 3mm thickness, which I know is probably way overkill. After using for a while, I may cut those down to provide a little more room in the drawer, and to save on filament.

I printed both of these at 100% and the tolerance for the drawer was about perfect. It slides easily without any noticeable left/right wobble, and the front sits flush with the rest of the stand when closed.

Need a place to put your picos when driving? Does your car have a cassette deck? https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2768508

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Could probably look really nice at a higher resolution, but I printed at 0.3mm to save time and it still looks pretty good.

I liked the idea of the y-lock and the original was good, but I like a little "fancier" so I tweaked it up a bit.  Made the latch stronger, added the Printrbot logo, and added a second mount hole giving you positioning choices. Hope you like it.

The STL is in MM. Load and print- works fine even with a .1 (10%) infill. After you print, you might like to color the logo with a permanent ink marker (I used black marker on my clear print). Use one of the two holes with the existing bolt on the y carriage frame. You can decide if you wan the y pulled in a bit further which on my Simple XL gets the y carrige extruder end all the way over the print bed and therefore better protected (I think). A good picture of approximately how this should be mounted is here:
http://thingiverse-production.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/0e/5b/83/17/ee/20140202_094255_preview_featured.jpg
